ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: No hours needed to spend on it.
1 hour.
N/A
1 hr

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Dr. Tschudi and Melanie are the best

This class was boring but necessary because I did learn things that are important in conducting research. Some of the guest lecturers were very dry and people seemed to have a hard time paying attention. Maybe more time allotted for questions and discussion would make the course more interesting.
Pretty useful in that letting us know something about honor code, academic conduct.

So, I think this was actually a good course for first year PhD students to tackle a bunch of issues that they'll confront in their careers. It was also the ONLY time when early current PhD students are in one place together. While it seems like it largely exists to deal with NIH requirements for funding, the forum turned out to be a useful one for at least my cohort of students.
Helpful in highlighting ethical and other situations we may encounter as we move forward in our careers.
Very, very useful and helpful course/seminar. Not what I was expecting based on the title, but very practical.Would have liked to have had access to presentations through classesv2.
Strengths: discussion of interesting and mostly relevant issues for PhD students.Weaknesses: more case examples and discussion could be nice
Learned a lot
very useful!
This course was a basic overview of topics in research - ethics, peer review etc. It accomplished what it set out to do and was not burdensome. Overall, I think Dr. Tschudi's approach was great.
I thought that some of the topics were actually quite useful.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Excellent

Instructor: Christian Tschudi  He kept a class that could be exceedingly boring and not useful fairly relevant. He didn't take it too seriously but also didn't completely blow it off and he got the required info across.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi and Melanie are the best
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Chris is great!
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  The instructor prepares the lectures with great care.

Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Chris is a great, sympathetic and avuncular teacher. We're lucky to have him as the director of the PhD program. He clearly cares about graduate education, which for some professors at Yale is something they don't really care about (i.e. they want grants and publications, students' welfare is secondary).
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  I thoroughly enjoy listening to Dr. Tschudi. He was very informative and I appreciated learning about his experiences as a researcher.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Excellent instructor, very approachable and sensitive to students' concerns.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Chris did a great job. Was sensitive to students interest and lack of interest in the topic.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Nice instructor
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi was responsive to students and respectful of our time. It is clear that he cares about the personal and professional well-being of EPH graduate students.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  Dr. Tschudi is a wonderful lecturer.
Instructor: Christian Tschudi  I appreciated Chris' openness and candid responses to student questions.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: An hour a week of sitting through discussion of ethical issues that crop up in research/academia...some of it is certainly relevant, but very little of it is actually interesting. Still, it's presented relatively well for what it is.
Dr. Tschudi and Melanie are the best
Pretty useful.
very useful
You have to take it, but it turns out to be a nice place to talk about the issues confronting researchers in training among a small group of your peers and with "elders" who can offer sound advice.
This is a good course to raise awareness about ethical situations we are likely to face as researchers.
I would definitely recommend this course to all PhD students, even if it would not be a course requirement.
Required class on ethics of research, writing and publication. Some interesting topics, others just required.
yes
